prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for scheduling my boyfriend with a male masseuse?
My boyfriend and I planned on getting massages together. A male and female masseuse were available, so I booked him (M/21) with the male and me (21/F) with the female. When I tell him about this, he says he will never let a man massage him. He explains that its because massages are inherently sexual. I believe massages are purely therapeutic so I try to discuss this and understand why he believes they are sexual and if he believes this, why it's then acceptable to even get a massage from the opposite sex in the first place since we are in a monogamous relationship. He says my opinion is irrational and I'm making it up just to argue- massages are clearly somewhat sexual and that I'm wrong for pushing for something he is uncomfortable with and turning it into an argument. I kept trying to explain I just wanted to understand his logic and hear his reasonings- kind of like a debate.  I even offered to switch masseuses. He then says to just cancel his massages and that this is too much trouble. I'm still going to go without him even after all this. AITA? 

&#x200B;
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for booking their boyfriend with a male masseuse. The author chose the male masseuse for him and the female for herself. The boyfriend then gets upset, saying massages are inherently sexual and refuses to go. The author tries to discuss it, offering to switch, but he insists on canceling.

First, I need to consider both sides. The author's reasoning is that massages are therapeutic, so choosing based on gender might not be necessary. They wanted to understand his perspective but kept pushing even after he was uncomfortable. The boyfriend's stance is that for him, opposite-sex massages are a turn-off and makes him uncomfortable. He felt the author was arguing instead of respecting his boundaries.

Is the author at fault? Well, even if the author thinks massages are non-sexual, they should respect the boyfriend's feelings. Insisting on their choice after he's uncomfortable could be seen as dismissing his feelings. The author tried to debate rather than just accept his discomfort. Offering to switch might show willingness to compromise, but the boyfriend didn't want to switch and ended up canceling. The key here is consent and comfort. The author might not have overstepped, but pushing the discussion might have caused more stress. The boyfriend's refusal to go at all could be his own choice, but the author's approach might have been inconsiderate. So, maybe the author is in the wrong for not respecting his boundaries enough. Answer A.
